document.text: Writing to you with a good ap petite, love abounding for all, and laughing at the ground 1 ogs di dos I have no special news this a. n., nothing startling, I am glad to sav have heard of no serious ca lamity to any. Some are still sick. Our cld comrade Thos. H. OBrien, is right much under the weather. Hope he will soon be himself again. Tom was one of the first to leave the county for the army. He was in most of the battles from Rich Mountain July 61 to Appcmattox April 65. Good soldier he was. The old fellows are on the march on the western slope, still in an en emys country. Say old fellow have you got on the right uniform, marching under the right captain, rmed with the proper implements? By or Her of the Captain read Eph.  11-18 sod sing When the Roll is  ailed up Yonder Ill be There. Well, God bless the -old veterans. Amen.

Mary Frances Jefferson Graves. 88. widow of Frank Peyton Graves, died January 3 in a Staun ton hospital after an extended ill ness. Surviving are a daughter, Mary Graves, of Appomattox, and two brothers, O. F. Jefferson and 0. G. Jefferson, both of Roanoke. Funeral services were conducted from New Hope Baptist Church on Tuesday at 1100 A. M., by the Rev. J. P. Leitner. Interment was in the church cemetery. Active pallbearers were Milton L, Hudson, H. A. document.text: Without the help of thous- sands of contributing Virgin ians, the Commonwealths Lions Clubs could never have pulled it off. With that help, a new dimension has been added to the rehabilitation of the Mind. When Virginia decided to build its recently dedicated Rehabilitation Center for the Blind, the plans included a recreation wing. Lack of immediate funds from the state, however, curtailed con struction of that wing, the main structure itself requiring hun dreds of thousands of dollar. Into the breach stepped the Lions Club of Virginia, which jointly agreed to come up with the 230,000 in matching funds to go along with a similar sum available from the federal government. Now that 460000 wing i opened and the vital recreation al aspects of rehabilitation are part of the States humanitar-  ian system of restoring norma lity to those stricken with blindness. Recreation put an afflicted person right back into the mainstream with his unaf fected friends and companions. Members of the local Lions Club shared in this worthy project by donating a total of 670.00 last year to the Virginia Rehabilitation Center in Rich mond, according to Dr. C. O. OBrien, Chairman of the Sight Conservation Committee of the Uotas Club ot Appomattox. Local Lions, with Sight. Conservation as their pet project, during the year raised money through the White Cap  81 and the Broom Sale, both annual fund raising project of 1 the local club. The club iso  collected app.oiliuately IVb pairs of glasses donated by the citizens of the county that are provided to worthy applicants, and have purchased 15 pairs of glasses at a cost of 806.00 for persons needing assistance. Appomattox Lions, being interested in preventing blind ness, contributed last year 350.00 to the Old Dominion Eye Bank and Research, Inc., and they have 102 eye donor cards that may be used someday to enable a blind person to see again with a corneal transplant. The Pre vention of the Blind Society is another good organization in Virginia and last year local Lions donated 100.00 to them. Another facet of the work being done by this service dub was the sponsoring last year of the Glaucoma Clinic in the Spring. It was a tremendous success and a project the Appomattox Lions can truly be proud of. . . they feel that it is of great importance to help prevent blindness if at all possible, and, too, it i important to do whatever can be done to help blind persons lead a normal life. ACTIVITIES B o w l i n g ? Swimming? Gymnasium - play room? Dayroom with televis ion, yes all of these can be enjoyed by the blind, and through the efforts of the Lions Clubs in the State of Virginia, these, plus an Assembly Hall for various programs and entertain, are all an integral part of the Rehabilitation Center For The Blind and are located in the recreation wing Contd on Page 13

document.text: With sixteen new teachers in place the white schools of Appomattox co unty opened this morning. The an nual pre-opening teachers meeting as -held here yesterday. Negro schools open tomorrow. A vacancy in the local faculty, caused by the resignation of Miss Kate OBrien to accept a position in Farmville as librarian, was filled by Professor M-urrie Bates, former prin- cipal of the Pamplin high school. Two of last years teachers were called by the United States Army, Professors Vanderslice and OBrien. Parents have been urged to enroll their children on the opening day of school. However, no increase over last years enrollment was expected here. A half-day session was all that was in prospect today, as pupils were given their book lists and enrolled by their new teachers.

document.text: With a Fair Share Goal of 4500.00 set for Appomattox County for the American Cancer Crusade, reaching the goal is close at hand. Mrs. Marge Mims and Mrs. Beck Hudson, co-chairmen of the crusade for Appomattox County,- would like to remind volunteers to turn in contribu tions at the earliest possible date. April was the month, set aside as Cancer Control Month and we would like to have our county 100. If you - were missed by volunteers and would like to make a donation, please mail your check to either of . the co-chairmen or to Dr. C. , G. OBrien, President of the Appomattox County , Unit,

document.text: William Pitzer Gills, who died at his home, Locust Grove, Friday morning, was the son of James Thomas and Cornelia Terri 1 Pitzer Gills. Though jiorn in Buckingham county, he moved to Appomattox in his boyhood on account of the death of his father. He then made his home with his uncle, the late Will iam Gills, who for many years was treasurer of the the county. He at tended the first public school evei taught in this county, Judge David A. Christian being the teacher. Mr. Gills engaged in various aeti- ties until the infirmities or age made, it necessary for him to retire from, public life. He was a senool trus.et of Appomattox county also serving as clerk to the school board, man carrier on R. F. D. No. 2, employed at one time by the Norfolk and Wes tern Railway, besides managing his arm near Appomattox. He was a iason and a Woodman of the  orld, and a Democr t who was un- werving in his par loyaly. Fii nany-lyears he was a faithful dea- on of Liberty Baptist church and teacher in the Sunday School. The deceased was a man whose lie was marked by fidelity to prin- ple. His was a goodly heritage of u ture and Godliness from an an cestry distinguished in the early history of America. Those who came in con4act with him were impressed by the deep spirituality of his nature. t  The funeral took place Sunday afternoon at Liberty Baptist church The Rev. H. Frederick Jones, the pastor, and the Rev. William May- field Thompson, a former pastor, conducting the services. The choir ,f the church sang Mr. Gills favor ite hymn, Rock of Ages. Tenny sons immortal poem, Crossing the Bar, was read and played on the pipe organ as a processional. Inter ment took place in the family plot in Liberty Cemetery, that part of the service. being conducted by the Masonic order. A host of friends and acquaintances, with many beautifa floral tributes attested to the love and high regard in which Mr. Gills was held in Appomattox and through out the state. Ihe active pallbearers were A. T. Inge, C. S. McDeormon, R. L. j Burk?, A. R. Harwood, J. C David son, N R. Featherston, B. G. An derson, Luther J. Morris. Honorary pallbearers included R. B. Hudgins, J. H. Lucado, T. W. Moses, Charles T. Moses, Pat Chand ler, L. Crawley, C. W. Smith, W. Stratton Taylor, Jennings Ferguson. T. Ed Owen, W. J. LeGrand, Dr. D. A. Christian, Dr. C. Cawthorn, O. Cleveland Paulette. T. Morton Rosser, R. W. Smith, Leslie N. Ligon, L. E. Smith, C. N. Abbitt, J R Horsley, J. E. Chick, W. L. Brown, L. F. Ferguson, O P. Farrar, J. H. Mr. Gills was first married to Miss Ella Pittman, who died some years ago. Two of the children of this union survive him, Henry Pitzer Gills of Marion, Virginia, and Mr 3 . Luth er B. Pittman, of Richmond. His second wife, who survives him, was Miss Albertha OBrien Of this mar riage, six children wire torn, James, passing away in inf.-ncy. The five living are Professor Allen Gils, of Clarksville Miss Cornelia Kyle Gills, of Appomattox Shelby Ken- nard Gills, of Richmond Mrs. Will iam Haller Copenhaver, of Marion Mrs. R. Banks Frazier, of Richmond. He also leaves five grandchildren, Mrs. R. S. Simpkins, of Chrisians- burg, Va. Mrs. Allen B. Pearcy, of Bristol, Penn. Gills, of Lynchburg, his only other brother being the late Edmond Ernest Gills, of Appomattox. document.text: William D. OBrien APPOMATTOX  William David OBrien, 64, of Rt. 2, Ap pomattox, died Tuesday morn ing in Lynchburg General Hos pital. His wife is Bessie Gunter OBrien., Born in Appomattox County, he was a son of the late William Walker OBrien and Mary Nowlin OBrien. He was a re tired farmer, a member and deacon of New Hope Baptist Church where he was the Sun day school superintendent, and a member of Oakville Ruritsh Club. In addition to his wife, he is survived by three sisters, Mrs. Adolph Haug of Norfolk, MrS. Maurice McGill of Appomattox and Mrs. C. W. Perkins of Richmond four brothers, R. Albert OBrien of Oklahoma City, Okla., Garland P. OBrien of Baltimore, Maynard G. OBrien of Lynchburg and Hiram L. OBrien of Richmond and 11 nieces and nephews. Funeral services will be con ducted at 11 a.m. Thursday at New Hope Baptist Church by the Rev. Clarence Davis, with burial in the church cemetery.

document.text: will meet on Thursday, October 22 at 645 in the Appomattox County High School cafeteria for its 42nd Year Anniversary Charter Night and Ladies Night. Two charter members. Dr. Clyde G. OBrien and former congressman Watkins M. Ab- bitt are still active in the organization. Woody Landers of Richmond, will entertain the group with tiis magic performance. He is with Westinghouse Credit Corporation as a sales repre sentative. Landers is presently serving his seventh year as territory rice-president of International Brotherhood of Magicians. He is a member of the Society of American Magicians and has performed for his fellow magicians. Coloring contest offered It will soon be that time. You know, when die winds Mow at night with an eerie sound, the leaves rustle in a frightening way and witches take to their brooms for the night.,....itll soon be Hallo ween. Its a special time for children and the TIMES-VIR GINIAN wants to make it - extra special. In this weeks issue of the TIMES-VIRGINIAN is a color ing contest. Children may enter one of five categories, pre school, kindergarten, grades one, two and three. For the first place winner in each category, the TIMES-VIR GINIAN will award a 10.00 first prize and a 5.00 second prize. As evidenced by last years coloring contest held at the Thanksgiving season, Appo mattox County is fall of budding artists. So, get out your colors, you may. use any kind you like. and do your best, t . Contestants are asked t o  take the completed picture to one of the advertisers whose names appear on the page with the ad. The entries will be j picked up by TIMES-VIR GINIAN staff members and judged by art teachers from the local school system. Entries must be completed and - returned to one of the places of business no later than October 30 at 5 p.m. The names of winners in each category will be published in the TIMES-VIRGINIAN for November 4.
